crossref_summary: Across 68 transcripts (48 host, 20 guest), the dominant trust pattern is personal vetting and human proof-of-legitimacy, not platform reviews. Hosts ask 'How do I know you're legit?' (Tag, Michael Spear, Patricia, Jessica Filomeno) and resolve it through LinkedIn profiles, success stories, sample contracts, and the agent's personal credibility -- never through a review system. Guests demand to 'see the space' and 'make sure everything is legit' (Susan Bryant) before committing. Hosts who have Airbnb reviews wield them as marketing weapons (Ramsey's 4.99 rating with 76 reviews), and Bryant proactively offers to port those reviews to Split Lease listings. The transcripts reveal a trust ecosystem built entirely on human intermediation and personal reputation signals, with zero infrastructure for post-stay review capture, mid-stay feedback, reviewer identity, or review-to-retention loops. Every Layer 1 disappointment is validated: the review system these users need does not exist in any form -- not broken, but absent. The most striking finding is that hosts already perform reviewer-like behavior (Tammy vets guests by employer/work location/purpose; Lilly demands proof of employment and landlord references) but this vetting intelligence is never captured as review-equivalent data for future guests or hosts.

new_discoveries.relates_to_competitor: Booking.com and Airbnb's review systems promise bidirectional accountability. But when hosts feel the system is stacked against them (guest complaints get instant refunds, host damage claims get ignored, pandemic cancellations are one-sided), the review system becomes a weapon aimed at them rather than a tool that serves them. Multiple hosts in the transcripts have fled Airbnb specifically because the review/accountability system failed to protect their interests.
new_discoveries.framework_analysis: Per Eyal's complete Hook Model, when the Variable Reward phase delivers negative outcomes (punitive guest reviews, one-sided dispute resolution), the entire hook cycle becomes aversive rather than attractive. The investment the host made (listing creation, review accumulation) becomes a liability rather than stored value. Tammy and Tag demonstrate the endpoint: complete hook cycle rejection. For Split Lease, this represents both a massive opportunity (these hosts are seeking an alternative) and a design warning (the review system must demonstrably protect both sides).

library_connections.connection: works-004 ('Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming') addresses the same trust vacuum that disappoint-010 identifies. The element prescribes explicit priming from phone calls to platform, agent photos on dashboards, and personalized first touchpoints. For new listings without reviews, this element's approach -- transferring trust from human relationships to digital signals -- is exactly what would fill the review desert with alternative trust mechanisms.

works-003 ('Match the Platform's Cognitive Speed to the Phone Call's Conversational Speed') prescribes that platform interactions should match conversational efficiency. The Tax Form Review (disappoint-001) violates this principle by forcing a high-friction, non-conversational form where a simple 'How was move-in? One tap.' would match the conversational speed users expect.

works-005 ('Engineer the Host-as-Advisor Moment to Lock Commitment') prescribes creating moments where hosts contribute expertise. The Wasted Booking Moment (disappoint-006) could be transformed using this pattern: asking the guest 'What matters most to you about this stay?' at booking time is an advisor moment that seeds review expectations while creating commitment.

works-006 ('Translate Between the Host's Mental Model and the Platform's Data Model') addresses the same category mismatch that disappoint-005 identifies. Just as hosts think in monthly rent while platforms think in nightly rates, long-term renters think in 'maintenance responsiveness' while Booking.com thinks in 'Staff score.' The translation principle should extend to review categories: capture reviews in the user's native quality dimensions, then translate to platform categories.

works-001 ('System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition') requires that each transition pass an automatic legitimacy check. The Reviewer Who Doesn't Exist (disappoint-003) means the review system itself fails this trust gate -- when a prospective guest encounters anonymous, identity-less reviews, System 1 cannot assess reviewer credibility, reducing trust in the entire review section.
